texas_news.headline: Texas DSHS Adopts Emergency Rule: No THC Sales to Anyone Under 21
texas_news.summary: On October 3, 2025, the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) adopted emergency rules requiring all retailers to verify ID for consumable hemp products, banning sales to anyone under 21. This follows Governor Abbott's Executive Order GA-56 from September 10, 2025. The rule affects approximately 8,000 licensed hemp businesses across Texas. TABC began enforcing similar rules on October 1, 2025. Violations may lead to license revocation.
texas_news.advocacy_opportunity: Public safety - advocate for smart regulation over prohibition

texas_news.headline: Texas Bans All Vapes Containing Cannabinoids - Businesses Face Up to 1 Year in Jail
texas_news.summary: On September 1, 2025, Senate Bill 2024 (SB 2024) took effect, prohibiting the sale and marketing of any vape product containing cannabinoids - whether THC, CBD, Delta-8, or THCA. Violations carry steep penalties: a Class A misdemeanor punishable by up to one year in jail and a $4,000 fine per offense. This has significantly impacted hemp dispensaries across Texas.
texas_news.advocacy_opportunity: Criminal justice reform - highlight the human cost of prohibition; Economic opportunity - show how regulation can create jobs and tax revenue

texas_news.headline: Court Blocks Austin's Marijuana Decriminalization - Arrests Resume
texas_news.summary: In April 2025, a court ruling blocked Austin's marijuana decriminalization policy, allowing police to resume arresting individuals for low-level cannabis possession. This follows Attorney General Ken Paxton's January 2024 lawsuit against Austin, Killeen, Denton, San Marcos, and Elgin to block local ordinances.
texas_news.advocacy_opportunity: Criminal justice reform; State vs. federal rights

texas_news.headline: Texas $5.5 Billion Hemp Industry Survives Another Ban Attempt
texas_news.summary: Hemp-derived THC products remain legal after Governor Greg Abbott vetoed a total ban in June 2025. Texas has an estimated $5.5 billion hemp industry with over 7,000 registered hemp dispensaries.

federal_news.headline: Trump Says He'll Decide on Cannabis Rescheduling 'In Coming Weeks'
federal_news.summary: Trump said he hopes to decide in the coming weeks about whether to support changes to marijuana regulation. He supports moving marijuana from Schedule 1 to Schedule 3. However, reclassifying would not make it legal for recreational use nationwide; rather, it would change regulation and taxation.
federal_news.advocacy_opportunity: State vs. federal rights; Economic opportunity

federal_news.headline: DEA Cancels Marijuana Rescheduling Hearing - Policy in Limbo
federal_news.summary: A hearing to assess the Biden administration's proposal to reschedule marijuana as Schedule III was cancelled by a DEA administrative law judge only eight days before the January 21, 2025 date. No decision was made before Biden left office.

culture_trends.headline: CaliSober Movement: 67% of Consumers Prioritize Wellness Over Recreation
culture_trends.summary: A 2025 report shows 67% of cannabis consumers now prioritize products aimed at relaxation or health benefits over recreational use. This represents a cultural shift toward viewing cannabis as a wellness tool.
